ayahs.text:
This verse begins with a divine oath by the winds that scatter things in the manner they are scattered. The winds scatter many things, such as the pollen from flowers which, with the help of winds, travel from one plant to another and help in fertilization. Similarly, seeds of many trees travel on the winds and reach distant areas, thus winds help in the growth and expansion of plants and forests.

The scattering winds represent one of the most visible manifestations of divine power in creation. They demonstrate how natural phenomena work according to divine command and serve multiple purposes - from pollination to seed dispersal to weather patterns. This oath by the winds draws attention to the systematic and purposeful nature of creation, where every element serves specific functions in maintaining the balance of life on earth.

This verse continues the divine oath with those that carry heavy loads. The winds carry billions of tons of water from the oceans in the form of clouds and transport them thousands of miles away, then cause rain to fall in different regions.

This remarkable process demonstrates the incredible power and precision of natural systems. The clouds serve as vehicles carrying life-giving water across vast distances, ensuring that rain reaches areas far from the oceans. This systematic distribution of water through atmospheric processes showcases the intricate design and balance that exists in creation, where each element works in harmony to sustain life on earth.

This verse refers to those that move gently and smoothly. Sometimes cool breezes blow in such a way that their gentle gusts bring great comfort to both plants and animals.

The gentle movement of winds demonstrates another aspect of natural phenomena - their capacity to bring ease and comfort. These soothing breezes provide relief and refreshment to all living creatures, showing how creation is designed not only for functionality but also for the well-being and comfort of life. This verse highlights the merciful aspects of natural forces that work to maintain a pleasant and habitable environment.

This verse speaks of those that distribute divine commands. This refers to the distribution of rainwater. Winds carry ocean water in the form of clouds to different regions, but where rain will fall and where it will not, and how much will fall where it does - all this happens according to divine command. The distribution of this divine command occurs through the winds.

We observe this distribution daily, where some areas become waterlogged with rain while other areas remain thirsty for every drop of water, and dark clouds pass over them without releasing rain. These verses, by taking oaths by the winds and mentioning various matters accomplished through them, actually invite contemplation of the universe's systematic order. If humans reflect on this, they will surely reach the conclusion that this universe has been created for humanity.

This verse, combined with verse 6, declares that what is being promised to you is certainly true, and recompense will definitely occur. This universe and its system bear witness that the news being given to you about resurrection after death, the first trumpet blast, the second trumpet blast, and other matters are certainly true, and there is no doubt about the punishment being threatened.

The Day of Judgment will certainly be established, and on that day all humans will definitely be brought back to life and will receive the reward for their deeds. The systematic order visible in creation serves as evidence for the certainty of divine promises about the afterlife and accountability.

This verse continues the declaration that recompense will definitely occur. The Day of Judgment will certainly be established, and on that day all humans will definitely be brought back to life and will receive the reward for their deeds.

The certainty of divine recompense is as firm as the natural laws governing the universe. Just as the winds, clouds, and rain follow precise patterns and commands, so too will divine justice be executed with perfect precision and timing. This verse emphasizes that accountability in the afterlife is not a matter of speculation but an established reality backed by the same divine power that maintains the cosmic order.

This verse contains an oath by the sky with its intricate patterns. This refers to the scene that the star-filled sky presents at night.

The night sky with its countless stars arranged in beautiful patterns serves as another sign of divine artistry and power. The intricate designs visible in the heavens demonstrate the precision and beauty inherent in creation. This celestial display invites contemplation of the Creator's wisdom and serves as a constant reminder of the order and purpose underlying the universe.

This verse states that people are certainly in contradictory speech regarding the afterlife. They have fallen into disagreement about the afterlife, and their statements differ from one another.

The confusion and contradictory opinions about fundamental spiritual truths reflect the state of those who reject divine guidance. While the natural signs are clear and consistent, people create various conflicting theories and beliefs about ultimate reality, life's purpose, and what happens after death. This intellectual chaos contrasts sharply with the clear and consistent message revealed through divine guidance.

This verse explains that only those are turned away from this message who have been turned away from divine guidance. Many among them do not pay attention to this revealed message and keep making up different stories about recompense.

However, the matter of recompense is a self-evident reality, and only that person will refrain from accepting it who has been rejected from the divine court and turned away from the paths of goodness and success. This verse indicates that rejection of clear truth is not due to lack of evidence but due to a spiritual condition that prevents proper understanding and acceptance of divine guidance.

This verse contains a curse upon those who engage in speculation and conjecture about divine matters. These are people who make guesses and spread false theories instead of accepting clear divine guidance.

Those who rely on speculation rather than revealed knowledge create confusion and lead others astray. Their conjectures about spiritual realities, the afterlife, and divine matters are not based on sound knowledge but on assumptions and wishful thinking. This verse condemns such an approach and emphasizes the importance of accepting divine revelation over human speculation.

This verse describes those who are immersed in heedlessness. They have neither knowledge of their purpose of creation nor concern for their ultimate destiny. They have even forgotten the covenant they made with Allah in the world of souls, as mentioned in Surah Al-A'raf, verse 172.

When humans come into this world, the recognition of that covenant exists within their souls. However, during worldly life, some people's souls become so drowned in heedlessness that they do not even remember this covenant made with their Lord. The verse refers to such people who have lost touch with their primordial nature and spiritual purpose due to excessive preoccupation with worldly matters.

This verse presents the mocking question of the disbelievers asking when the Day of Recompense will come. The polytheists would ask this question sarcastically, saying that the Prophet kept talking about the day of recompense coming, so when would that day of judgment actually arrive.

Their question was not sincere inquiry but rather mocking dismissal of divine warnings. They used the delay in immediate consequences as an excuse to continue their rebellious behavior, failing to understand that divine timing serves purposes beyond human comprehension, including providing opportunities for repentance and ensuring perfect justice when it does arrive.

This verse provides the answer to their mocking question - it will be the day when these people are roasted over the Fire. Since the polytheists asked this question in a frivolous manner, the response to them also carries a tone of rebuke.

The day they mockingly inquire about will become their day of severe trial and punishment. Their casual attitude toward divine warnings will be replaced by the harsh reality of experiencing divine justice. The fire mentioned here represents both the consequence of their choices and the purification of all falsehood and rebellion.

This verse contains the direct address that will be made to them on that day: 'Taste your trial! This is what you were seeking to hasten.' They used to challenge the Messenger, saying to bring punishment upon them if he could. So this is the answer to that demand of theirs today - now taste the pleasure of this punishment!

The punishment they will experience is directly connected to their mockery and challenges in worldly life. They demanded to see divine punishment as proof, and their demand will be fulfilled in a way they never expected. The irony is that what they sought as a challenge will become their torment, and they will realize too late the reality they had denied.

This verse declares that the righteous will certainly be in gardens and springs. This describes the blessed state awaiting those who lived with consciousness of Allah and maintained righteousness throughout their lives.

The gardens and springs represent the flourishing of their spiritual development and the eternal rewards for their good deeds. Unlike the punishment awaiting the mockers, the righteous will enjoy perpetual bliss and satisfaction in an environment that perfectly reflects their purified spiritual state and their commitment to divine guidance during their worldly existence.

This verse explains that they will be gratefully receiving what their Lord gives them, for they were righteous people before this. These people had reached the level of excellence (ihsan) in their worldly life due to their good deeds.

Their ability to receive divine gifts with pure gratitude and satisfaction reflects their spiritual development achieved during their earthly existence. The rewards they enjoy are not arbitrary gifts but the natural result of their spiritual cultivation and consistent righteous behavior. Their previous excellence in worship and conduct has prepared them to appreciate and benefit from divine bounty in the afterlife.

This verse describes one of the specific qualities of the righteous - they used to sleep very little during the night. Most of their nights were spent in the presence of their Lord. The practice of the 'servants of the Merciful' is mentioned in Surah Al-Furqan: 'And those who spend the night before their Lord, prostrating and standing.'

Their willingness to sacrifice sleep and comfort for spiritual communion demonstrates their prioritization of eternal over temporal concerns. Night worship represents the highest level of voluntary devotion, performed when no one is watching except Allah. This practice indicates deep spiritual commitment and genuine love for Allah, showing their understanding that spiritual advancement requires sustained effort beyond minimum obligations.

This verse mentions that in the pre-dawn hours, they would seek forgiveness. The time just before dawn is considered especially blessed for spiritual activities, as it represents the transition from darkness to light and symbolizes spiritual awakening and renewal.

Their consistent seeking of forgiveness during these blessed hours demonstrates their humility and recognition that even the righteous need continuous divine mercy. This practice reflects their understanding that spiritual purification is an ongoing process requiring daily attention, and that seeking forgiveness should be a regular practice rather than something done only when major sins are committed.

This verse states that in their wealth was a right for the beggar and the deprived. They had accepted the reality that whatever Allah had given them included a share for the poor and needy, and they used to deliver the rights of the relevant people to them.

They understood that true ownership belongs only to Allah and that human wealth carries social responsibilities. Their recognition of others' rights in their wealth established them as instruments of divine mercy in their communities, ensuring that divine provision reached all who needed it regardless of their ability to ask for help. This comprehensive approach to charity reflects genuine compassion and social awareness.

This verse declares that in the earth are signs everywhere for those who have certainty. The detailed mention of these signs of Allah is found in Surah Al-Baqarah, verse 164.

Every aspect of the natural world, from the smallest organism to the largest geological formation, bears witness to divine creativity, wisdom, and power. The earth serves as an open book of divine revelation for those who have developed the spiritual insight to read its messages. The signs encompass both the diversity and unity visible in earthly creation, demonstrating purposeful design that transcends random occurrence.

This verse directs attention to the signs within human beings themselves, asking 'Do you not see?' The human body and every system within it contains countless signs of Allah. Humans should contemplate these signs.

The signs within humanity include not only physical marvels like the complexity of various bodily systems but also psychological and spiritual capacities. The verse emphasizes that Allah has made humans the most honored of creation, and humans should reflect on their creation and existence to recognize their status and position. The question format implies that failure to recognize divine signs within oneself represents a profound form of spiritual blindness.

This verse declares that in the heaven is your sustenance and what is promised to you. Your sustenance from Allah is predetermined, and the decision of whether you go to paradise or hell is also according to His will.

The heaven represents the source of both material and spiritual blessings that make human life possible and meaningful. The connection between present provision and future promise demonstrates the consistency and reliability of divine care throughout time. This verse encourages believers to recognize the spiritual dimension of divine provision, understanding that both worldly sustenance and eternal rewards come from the same divine source.

This verse contains a powerful oath by the Lord of the heavens and earth, declaring that this is certainly true, just as you are speaking right now. That is, resurrection after death is inevitable, it is true, and the Day of Judgment will certainly come.

The comparison to human speech emphasizes the absolute certainty of divine promises by relating them to one of the most basic and undeniable human experiences. Just as no one doubts their ability to speak, no one should doubt the reality of divine accountability. The vastness of the oath by heaven and earth reflects the magnitude and certainty of what is being promised.

This verse asks if the news of Ibrahim's honored guests has reached you. This refers to the incident when angels came as guests in human form to Ibrahim's house.

The story of Ibrahim's hospitality serves as a model for believers and demonstrates how divine messengers often come in unexpected forms. The description of the guests as 'honored' emphasizes their high status in divine estimation, though this was not immediately apparent to Ibrahim. This narrative serves not merely as historical information but as practical guidance for developing the qualities of generosity and hospitality.

This verse describes the polite exchange when the guests entered and said 'Peace,' and Ibrahim also responded with 'Peace' and thought to himself that these were some unfamiliar people.

The exchange of peaceful greetings reflects the proper etiquette for human interactions. Ibrahim's response actually improved upon his guests' greeting, showing his commitment to excellence in courtesy. This detail illustrates the principle that when someone offers a good greeting, the response should be equally good or better, creating an atmosphere conducive to positive interaction.

This verse states that Ibrahim quietly went to his family and brought a roasted fat calf. In the old days, hospitality was conducted in this manner - an animal would be slaughtered and fried or roasted in ghee, then presented whole to the guests.

Ibrahim's swift action demonstrates exemplary hospitality, offering the best available food without delay. His choice of a calf indicates that he provided high-quality food worthy of honored guests, showing both generosity and respect for their dignity. The immediate preparation also demonstrates practical wisdom in maintaining a household ready to serve guests at any time.

This verse shows Ibrahim bringing the food near them and asking 'Will you not eat?' His respectful invitation demonstrates proper hospitality etiquette, offering food without pressure while making it easily accessible.

This detail illustrates the balance between generous offering and respectful restraint that characterizes excellent hospitality. Ibrahim neither forced food upon his guests nor remained distant from their needs, but found the middle path that combined active care with dignified respect for their autonomy.

This verse describes Ibrahim feeling apprehension about his guests when they did not eat the food. In the cultural context of his time, people maintained nobility even in enmity - if someone's salt was consumed, they would not think of harming that person afterward. The guests said 'Do not fear' and gave him the glad tiding of a knowledgeable son, referring to Ishaq, whose birth the angels announced.

Ibrahim's concern when his guests refused food was natural, as this could indicate suspicion or hostility. However, their abstention revealed their true nature as spiritual beings who do not require physical sustenance. The moment of revelation transformed the entire encounter from a simple hospitality story into a profound spiritual experience, showing how sincere good deeds often lead to unexpected divine blessings.

This verse describes how Ibrahim's wife came forward muttering, struck her forehead, and said 'An old barren woman will give birth?' She questioned how she could have a son when she had been barren her whole life and was now too old to become a mother.

Her reaction demonstrates the natural human response to news that seems impossible according to ordinary circumstances. Her astonishment reflects the miraculous nature of divine promises that transcend normal limitations. This response shows how divine announcements often challenge human expectations and require faith to accept what appears impossible by worldly standards.

This verse records the angels' response: 'Thus has your Lord said.' The angels, who were in human form, replied that this would certainly happen - they were not giving this news on their own but it was their Lord's decision. Indeed, He is the All-Wise, the All-Knowing.

The angels' response emphasizes that divine decisions are based on perfect wisdom and knowledge that transcends human understanding. Their reference to Allah's wisdom and knowledge provides assurance that what seems impossible to humans is well within divine capability, and that divine plans serve purposes that may not be immediately apparent to human perception.

This verse shows Ibrahim asking the messengers about their purpose and mission. What was their intention and objective? What special mission were they undertaking?

Ibrahim's inquiry demonstrates appropriate curiosity about divine plans and shows his involvement in divine affairs as a prophet. His question reflects both respect for the angels' status and genuine interest in understanding the broader implications of their visit. This shows how prophets serve as bridges between divine will and human concerns.

This verse records the angels' response that they had been sent to a criminal people. They explained their mission to destroy a community that had persistently rejected divine guidance and engaged in serious transgressions.

The angels' identification of their targets as 'criminal people' indicates that divine punishment is never arbitrary but always directed at those who have earned it through their choices and actions. This response explains the serious nature of their mission and connects Ibrahim's story to the broader narrative of divine justice operating throughout history.

This verse explains their mission: to rain stones of clay upon the transgressing people. These stones represent divine punishment precisely targeted and appropriate to the crimes committed.

The use of clay stones rather than other forms of destruction demonstrates the deliberate and controlled nature of divine justice. The specific mention of stones indicates that divine punishment is measured and purposeful, designed to address specific transgressions while demonstrating divine power over the elements of creation.

This verse states that these stones were marked by your Lord for the transgressors. Allah had designated each stone for a specific individual among them, and it would work like a bullet for that person.

The marking of stones emphasizes the precision and divine origin of this punishment. Each stone was designated for its specific target, ensuring that divine justice was both comprehensive and accurate. This detail demonstrates that divine punishment is never random or excessive but always proportional to crimes committed and carefully limited to those who deserve it.

This verse explains that the angels brought out whoever was among the believers in that city. The divine mercy that saved the faithful demonstrates that even in situations of general destruction, Allah protects those who maintain faith and righteousness.

The careful extraction of believers shows divine precision in applying both justice and mercy. This provides hope and encouragement for the faithful who find themselves surrounded by widespread wrongdoing, demonstrating that maintaining faith and righteousness is possible even in the most challenging circumstances.

This verse reveals that only one household of Muslims was found in that entire community - that of Lut. Except for Lut's household, there was no other Muslim in that entire nation.

The scarcity of believers in such a large community serves as both warning and lesson about how spiritual corruption can spread until only isolated individuals or families maintain true faith. This detail provides comfort to believers who feel isolated in communities where faith is rare, showing that divine protection depends on individual commitment rather than community acceptance.

This verse explains that Allah left a sign there for those who fear painful punishment. The settlements of Lut's people, Sodom and Gomorrah, were located on the seashore of what is now called the Dead Sea. The ruins mentioned here refer to the remains that Allah has made visible as a lesson for people until the end of time.

The preservation of these ruins demonstrates divine wisdom in providing concrete evidence of spiritual truths. The physical signs make abstract concepts of divine justice tangible and undeniable, serving as permanent reminders of the reality of divine accountability. However, their effectiveness depends on spiritual receptivity - those who maintain awareness of divine justice benefit from these reminders.

This verse mentions that there is also a sign in the story of Musa when he was sent to Pharaoh with clear authority. Musa represented divine guidance confronting worldly power and arrogance, carrying miraculous proofs that demonstrated divine supremacy over human authority.

The clear authority mentioned encompasses both the miraculous signs that Musa performed and the compelling logic of his message. This story serves as a pattern for understanding how divine guidance operates throughout history, always providing clear evidence while respecting human freedom to choose between submission and rebellion.

This verse describes how Pharaoh turned away in the pride of his power and said that Musa was either a sorcerer or a madman. Pharaoh gave Musa the same titles that the people of Mecca were giving to the Prophet.

Pharaoh's response exemplifies the typical pattern of how those in positions of worldly power respond to divine messengers - attempting to discredit them through personal attacks rather than addressing the substance of their message. This pattern repeats throughout history, revealing the weakness of opposition to divine truth and the limited nature of human objections to divine guidance.

This verse describes how divine justice overtook Pharaoh and his armies, casting them into the sea where he was blameworthy. The drowning of Pharaoh's forces demonstrates how divine power ultimately overwhelms all forms of human opposition.

The phrase 'We took him and his armies' emphasizes divine agency in their destruction, showing that their defeat was a direct divine intervention. The casting into the sea serves as both punishment and symbol, demonstrating how divine creation serves divine justice when necessary.

This verse mentions the sign in the people of 'Ad when a barren wind was sent against them. The word 'barren' means infertile, like a man or woman who cannot have children. In this context, it refers to a wind that was devoid of all good.

The choice of wind as the instrument of destruction is significant because the people of 'Ad were known for their physical strength and impressive constructions. Their confidence in their own power was challenged by something as seemingly simple as wind, demonstrating that divine power operates through means that human strength cannot resist or control.

This verse describes the comprehensive destructive power of the wind, stating that it did not leave anything it encountered without reducing it to fragments. The totality of the destruction demonstrates divine power that can completely transform landscapes when divine justice is implemented.

The complete destruction serves as a powerful reminder of human vulnerability and the temporary nature of all worldly achievements. Despite their impressive buildings and engineering accomplishments, all of 'Ad's works were reduced to nothing by divine action, showing that human pride in material achievement is ultimately misplaced.

This verse mentions the sign in Thamud when they were told to enjoy themselves until a certain time. This reprieve demonstrates divine mercy that provides opportunities for repentance even when communities have earned punishment.

The instruction to 'enjoy for a while' carries both mercy and warning, giving them a final chance to reconsider their rejection of divine guidance while indicating that their time was limited. This demonstrates that divine patience has bounds and that opportunities for repentance, while generous, are not infinite.

This verse describes how they rebelled against their Lord's command, and a thunderbolt seized them while they were watching. Their defiance represents the ultimate form of rebellion - knowingly rejecting divine guidance despite clear warnings.

The thunderbolt as their instrument of destruction differs from the gradual wind that destroyed 'Ad, demonstrating that divine justice manifests in various forms appropriate to different circumstances. The fact that they were watching when destruction came emphasizes their awareness and deliberate choice in the face of divine warnings.

This verse explains that after their punishment, they had neither the strength to stand nor the ability to take revenge. They could neither rise up nor defend themselves.

Their complete helplessness emphasizes the futility of opposing divine will and the impossibility of escaping divine justice once it has been decreed. This description serves as a humbling reminder about ultimate dependence on divine grace and the importance of maintaining submission to divine guidance rather than relying on human power and independence.

This verse mentions that the people of Nuh were also seized before them, for they were indeed a transgressing people. Their inclusion emphasizes that rejection of divine guidance and its consequences represent a consistent pattern throughout human history.

The people of Nuh represent one of the earliest examples of widespread corruption and divine intervention, showing that spiritual rebellion and its consequences have existed since early human civilization. The chronological reference demonstrates the continuity of divine guidance and justice throughout history.

This verse declares that the heaven was built with divine hands, and Allah is expanding it. The linguistic analysis shows that this refers to Allah continuously giving expansion to the universe, making it ever more vast. This understanding aligns with modern scientific knowledge about the expanding universe.

The expansion of the universe represents one of the most remarkable signs of divine power, demonstrating creative force that operates on scales beyond human comprehension. The ongoing expansion serves as evidence of divine control over cosmic forces and shows that divine creative activity is continuous rather than limited to a single moment in the past.

This verse states that the earth was spread out like a carpet, and Allah is the best of those who spread things out. The earth's preparation involved countless adjustments and provisions necessary to support life.

The spreading of the earth encompasses both its physical preparation and its spiritual significance as the arena for human moral development. The earth serves as both home and testing ground, providing the environment necessary for spiritual growth and demonstrating divine mastery in creation.

This verse explains that pairs were created of everything so that people might take heed. The creation of pairs provides lessons from many perspectives, and there is vast scope for research in understanding this.

The universal principle of pairing serves as a sign pointing to divine unity, showing that while creation exhibits diversity and complementarity, it originates from a single divine source. The verse suggests that since everything has a pair, this world should also have a pair, and clearly the world's pair is the afterlife, providing a rational argument for the existence of the hereafter.

This verse contains the command to flee to Allah, as the speaker is a clear warner from Him. If Allah's message has reached you and these words have been understood, then do not delay in turning to Allah. It is possible that the angel has already received the command to take your soul, and the time for your life's work is very near to ending.

The command to flee implies urgency and necessity, suggesting that seeking divine refuge is essential for human welfare and salvation. This flight to Allah encompasses both escape from what is harmful and movement toward what is beneficial, involving complete dependence on divine mercy and guidance as the only reliable source of security.

This verse warns against setting up any other deity alongside Allah, emphasizing that the speaker is a clear warner from Him. The warning against associating partners with Allah represents the most fundamental aspect of divine guidance.

This warning encompasses not only obvious forms of idol worship but also subtle forms of shirk such as excessive reliance on worldly means or pride in personal achievements. Pure monotheism requires recognizing Allah as the only ultimate reality deserving worship, trust, and submission.

This verse points out the historical pattern that no messenger came to previous peoples without them saying he was either a sorcerer or a madman. This pattern demonstrates the consistency of human resistance to divine guidance throughout history.

The repetition of the same accusations across different times and cultures reveals the limited nature of human objections to divine guidance. Despite the clarity and reasonableness of prophetic messages, opponents consistently resort to the same types of character attacks rather than addressing the substance of divine guidance.

This verse asks whether they made a pact with each other about this response. The same statements that people made to their prophets centuries ago are exactly what the Quraysh of Mecca are saying to the final Messenger today. Did each generation leave these responses as a legacy to the next generation? Rather, they are all rebellious people.

The similarity in rejections across time and place results not from coordination but from the common tendency of rebellious hearts to resist divine guidance in predictable ways. Their shared spiritual condition produces similar responses to prophetic messages, regardless of their specific cultural or historical contexts.

This verse instructs the Prophet to turn away from the deniers, assuring him that he bears no blame. If they have gone so far in their opposition as to call him a poet, sorcerer, madman, or one who has been taught, and they continue to reject his call, then he should also turn his attention away from them.

The assurance that the Prophet is not blameworthy provides comfort from the natural tendency of sincere messengers to feel responsible for others' rejection of guidance. This principle applies to all believers who strive to share divine guidance - after making sincere efforts to convey truth clearly, they should not feel guilty if others choose rejection.

This verse encourages continued reminding, noting that reminders benefit the believers. The Prophet should continue the process of teaching and preaching. If rebellious people ignore these reminders, it does not matter - they are very beneficial for the believers.

This verse provides guidance for all who engage in religious education, showing that consistent reminding serves important purposes even when dramatic conversions do not result. The accumulative effect of divine reminders helps believers deepen their understanding and strengthen their commitment over time.

This verse declares that jinn and humans were created only to worship Allah. This verse is very important as it explains the purpose of human creation. While the reason for the universe's creation is a complex question, knowing one's own purpose of creation is essential for every human being.

If humans do not know their purpose of creation, their entire life will be wasted. This verse clearly tells humanity that they were created for Allah's worship. Worship consists of complete obedience and ultimate love for Allah, along with the rituals of worship. True worship involves recognizing Allah as the only being worthy of absolute submission and organizing one's entire life around divine guidance.

This verse emphasizes that Allah wants no sustenance from them, nor does He want them to feed Him. This divine independence means that worship benefits the worshiper rather than fulfilling any divine need.

The mention of provision and sustenance highlights the complete reversal of normal relationships, where Allah is the universal provider while His creation is entirely dependent. No human action can add to or subtract from divine perfection, making worship a privilege rather than a burden.

This verse affirms that Allah is the Provider, the Possessor of Power, the Strong. This divine role as provider encompasses both material and spiritual sustenance, ensuring that all creation receives what it needs for survival and development.

The mention of divine power and strength emphasizes that Allah's provision is not limited by any external constraints. Divine ability to provide exceeds all possible needs and demands, ensuring that provision is always adequate and available for those who seek it appropriately.

This verse warns that the wrongdoers have a share of punishment like their companions had, so they should not ask for haste. The word 'dhanub' refers to a bucket filled to the brim with water. This means that like the nations of the past who faced punishment, the cup of these disbelievers' misdeeds has also overflowed.

The bucket can be drawn at any time now. So even if their immediate punishment is not occurring, they should not think they will be left alone. This establishes the principle that divine justice operates consistently, ensuring that wrongdoing receives appropriate consequences regardless of when or where it occurs.

This final verse of Surah Adh-Dhariyat pronounces woe and destruction upon those who persistently reject divine guidance, warning them about their promised day of reckoning. The woe mentioned here represents the inevitable consequences that await those who choose disbelief over faith despite receiving clear guidance and ample opportunities for repentance. This conclusion serves as both a solemn warning and a final call to consciousness.

The reference to 'their day' emphasizes the certainty and personal nature of divine accountability, indicating that the Day of Judgment is as real and inevitable as any appointment they might have in this world. Despite their denial, dismissal, or mockery of divine warnings, this day will arrive exactly as promised, and they will face the consequences of their choices and actions.

The surah's conclusion with this warning brings the entire chapter full circle, returning to the themes of resurrection, judgment, and divine justice that were established in the opening verses. After presenting extensive evidence through natural signs, prophetic narratives, and logical arguments, the surah ends with this stark reminder that the choice between faith and disbelief carries eternal consequences, making immediate consideration and response both urgent and wise.
